title-group.article-title: Native and cross-linked modified Dioscorea trifida (cush-cush yam) starches as bio-matrices for edible films

article-meta.aff: 1Instituto de Ciencia y Tecnología de Alimentos, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad Central de Venezuela, Caracas, Venezuela
2College of Social Sciences, University of Phoenix, Yuma, USA

author-notes.corresp: Elevina Pérez, Instituto de Ciencia y Tecnología de Alimentos, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad Central de Venezuela, Apartado 47097, Caracas 1041-A, Venezuela. Email: perezee@hotmail.com; elevina.perez@ciens.ucv.ve

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Native and modified starches from non-conventional sources could be used as raw materials that represent appropriate bio-matrices to support diverse bioactive substances when formulating composite edible films or foams. In order to be used as raw materials, the starch and the starch-based films or foams obtained have to be characterized. The goals of this study were first, to isolate the starch from the edible portion of Dioscorea trifida, a sub-utilized agricultural commodity of the Venezuelan Amazons; second, to modify by cross-linking the native starch already isolated with sodium trimetaphosphate; third, to produce edible films with both the native and modified starches; and finally to characterize both while comparing their functional properties and proposing them to be utilized to produce foams. The bio-matrices represented by native and modified starches were used to formulate films with 5% of D. trifida starch and 1.5% glycerol. A native D. trifida starch with high purity was obtained, as well as a cross-linked modified starch with a 0.002% of degree of substitution. Significant statistical differences in the film thickness, color profile, deformation, and stress to puncture were found in both types of films. The modified starch-based films exhibited higher width and opalescence than those formed with native starch. The water vapor permeability, water retention, and water solubility differed also between both bio-matrices. The results suggested, in spite of these differences, that both of them could be proposed for gasification in order to obtain foams.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The natural polymers are resources widely found in the environment. Indeed, because of their polymeric structure, they can easily be modified and they tend to be readily biodegradable. They are also ubiquitous and cheap. Cellulose, starch, lignin, chitin, and various polysaccharides are included in this group.

Starch consists primarily of d-glucopyranose polymers linked by α-1,4, and α-1,6 glycosidic bonds. Glucose polymerization in starch results in two types of polymers: amylose and amylopectin. Amylose is considered to be an essentially linear polymer composed almost entirely of a α-1,4-linked d-glucopyranose or maltose units. Recent evidence has suggested that some branches are present on the amylose polymer, whereas the amylopectin molecule is much larger and more branched. The structural differences between these two polymers contribute to significant differences in their functionality and make possible their modification.1

The best option, also an innovative idea, when developing a new biodegradable product is the use of natural resources as a source of conservation and recycling. The entire replacement of synthetic plastics by biodegradable materials for the foam elaboration has not been obtained until the present; however, some synthetic polymers have been replaced by other natural ones for specific applications. Such replacements have allowed product development with specific characteristics related to the barrier, mechanical, and thermal properties in certain packing such as films, covers, foams, envelopes, plates, spoons, and bags.2,3

Native or modified starches are some of the polymeric substances considered to be used as bio-matrices appropriate for films4 or these starches could be processed into foam by applying suitable methods. Additionally, starch is cheap, abundant, easy to handle, and biodegradable. They also provide supporting matrix for many of the composite foams and films studied, and generally, when they are mixed with plasticizers and lipids, they offer good barrier properties to gases and water. Moreover, mixing them with other kinds of polymeric components can also provide a selective barrier to the oxygen and carbon dioxide.5 Furthermore, a variety of crystalline, fibrous, amorphous, or metallic additives may be incorporated into the foam structure to produce lightweight composite materials with enhanced strength and insulating properties.2 Moreover, its native structure is very effective when producing foams, but most efficient when modified by cross-linking.

The ability of starch to undergo modification using different methods has been investigated extensively to obtain starch with improved functional properties for diverse uses. In fact, the use of modified starches as bio-matrices has been investigated in order to optimize some of the functional properties considered as limits for its uses in the formation of foams, edible films, and coatings. Therefore, the use of physical and chemical modifications, such as extrusion,6 oxidation, acetylation,7 and the use of starch with high and low amylose content8 have been investigated in terms of the functional properties of the starch-based films. On the other hand, some applications of native9–11 and modified11–14 starches for the elaboration of bio-foams have been reported in literature. Results have shown that modifications have improved the functional properties on foams and films, such as its anti-leakage ability for vegetable oil, good stability in acid aqueous medium, gas permeability, cell development, density, tensile strength, sealing resistance, expansion, and compression stress.

The use of edible films and coatings in staple food may improve and keep their functional properties. Also, the films can be carriers of bioactive substances that will improve the nutritional or nutraceutical properties of the food15–17 and stability. In addition to the increasing concerns about environmental protection and garbage handling, renewable natural materials such as starches are becoming popular in the manufacture of packaging materials, especially bio-foams.

In the tropics, there are numerous sources of starch that can be suitable for such uses. Dioscorea trifida, a sub-utilized agricultural commodity of the Venezuelan Amazons, is an important specie of the Dioscoreaceae family that grows in tropical areas, especially in the northern region of South America. Tubers of D. trifida are an important source of starch (58–64% db)18 and their exploitation should be considered for commercial uses. Biopolymers extracted from agricultural non-conventional commodities, such as D. trifida, can be excellent raw materials for edible biologically degradable plastics. A very important feature is that starch from this crop has been analyzed and reported as a waxy starch.18

The goals of this study were first to isolate starch from D. trifida and modify the native starch by cross-linking to characterize and compare both starches as well as produce and characterize edible films. And finally with the starch-based films, formulated in terms of physicochemical properties, evaluate its potential as an ingredient to produce foams.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: White D. trifida tubers were gathered from the farms of Guiria, Sucre State, Venezuela.

sec.title: Starch isolation
sec.p: Two batches of native starch were isolated from D. trifida tubers grown in Venezuelan farms. The cleaned tubers were peeled and their edible portions were sliced. Approximately 0.5 kg of the edible portion was mixed for 2 min in a waring blender with twice their volume of distilled water. This procedure was repeated six times to process approximately 3 kg. The collected homogenate was passed through a 200-mesh sieve. The grinding and screening operations were repeated four more times. The resulting slurry was centrifuged at 1500 r/min for 15 min, at ±28°C, to facilitate separation of the starch from the viscous mucilage. After carefully removing the remaining mucilaginous layer, the sediment was washed several times by suspending in distilled water and centrifuging until it appeared free of non-starch material. The sediment was then dried in a ventilated oven at 45°C. Starches were blended, passed through a 60-mesh sieve, and stored at room temperature in sealed plastic bags inside hermetic glass containers until subsequent analysis.18

sec.title: Starch modification
sec.p:
Starch modification with sodium trimetaphosphate (STMP) was performed following a wet procedure19 with some modifications (Figure 1). Native starch (300 g) and 15 g of sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) were suspended in 300 mL of distilled water. The solid content in the suspension has to reach 24 B° (Baumé degree). The pH of the suspension was adjusted to 11 with 2.5% NaOH solution. The slurry was heated at 45°C to proceed with the addition of 2 g of STMP. The slurry was held under agitation for 3 h. The pH of the slurry was adjusted every hour to 11, if it was necessary. After 3 h, the pH was lowered to 7 with 2.5% HCl solution. The slurry was washed three times by suspension in distilled water, centrifuged at 1500 r/min for 15 min, and dried at 45°C. The dried modified starch was milled and sieved through a 60-mesh sieve. Figure 1.
Flow sheet of starch modification (Lim and Seib19). STMP: Starch modification with sodium trimetaphosphate.

sec.title: Film elaboration
sec.p:
Film-forming solutions in distilled water with 5% (w/v) D. trifida starch and 1.5% (w/v) of glycerol were prepared, homogenized with an Ultra Turrax T25 with a dispersing device (IKA® Werke) placed in a water bath at 95°C, and maintained at 95°C for 30 min with gentle magnetic stirring until the starch was fully gelatinized. After gelatinization, each gel suspension was degassed for 15 min with a vacuum mechanical pump. Aliquots of 60 mL of each film-forming solution, still hot and fluid, were poured onto 14 cm diameter plastic petri dishes and dried in a stove at 50°C for 24 h (Figure 2).20 Figure 2.
Flow sheet of elaboration of starch-based edible films.

sec.title: Starch and film analysis
sec.p: Native and modified starches were evaluated: moisture and ash by gravimetric method,21 crude protein (N × 6.25) by micro-Kjeldahl,21 and the fatty material by acid hydrolysis.22 Also, relative density, pH, and titratable acidity were determined,21 and finally, their amylose content was determined by colorimetric micro-procedure that is based on the formation of the complex amylose and iodine,23 and by the differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) technique with a DSC 7 (Perkin Elmer, Norwalk, USA).24,25 DSC analysis was not performed on the modified starch because of the steric effect produced by the substitution of the amylaceous molecules with the cross-linked phosphates, which shall avoid the reaction with the lysophosphatidylcholine. Purity of the native starch was calculated from the equation: Purity (%) = 100 − (moisture content (%) + crude protein (%) + fatty materials (%) + ash (%))

Phosphorous and the degree of substitution (DS) of the native and modified starches were determined by the colorimetric method22 using the equations proposed by Deetae et al.26. Color and white index (WI) of the native and modified starches and films were obtained by a Colorimeter Macbeth model Color-eye 2445 with CIE LAB scale,27 and the Hsua et al.28 equation. The films obtained were also evaluated by measuring aw with an AquaLab Dew Point Water Activity Meter 4TE (Decagon Devices, Inc., Pullman, USA),29 pH,21 width (with a digital micrometer),30 standard penetration test (with a Stable Micro System TA-XT2i texture analyzer,31 water permeability,32 water solubility, and water retention.33 Visual film porosity and appearance were determined using a Stuart SC6 magnifier colony counter.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Analysis of variance at the significant level of 5% (0.05) was performed to obtain the results using the Statgraphics Program (Statically Graphics Educational, version 6.0 1992. Manugistics, Inc. and Statistical Graphics Corp., USA). When statistical differences were found, the Duncan’s multiple range test was applied at the significant level of 5% (0.05) to classify the samples.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Table 1 presents the native D. trifida starch showing quite high purities and a cross-link-modified starch with a 0.002% DS. Significant differences (p < 0.05) were found in the amylose contents of both native and modified starches (Table 1). A decrease of the amylose content by the effect of the treatment with STMP was observed. Some authors34 have shown that the identity of the major chromophore formed in the amylose–iodine reaction was a pentaiodide anion I5−. Then, it is inferred that cross-linking represents in the modified starch a steric effect that prevents the formation of the chromophore and hence provide a non-optimal quantification of the amylose. The amylose content obtained by DSC in the native starch was more realistic (waxy starch) than that obtained by the chromophore formation. Table 1.
Purity and DS of the native and modified D. trifida starches
Parameters Native Modified
Moisture (%) 11.75 ± 0.05a 10.19 ± 0.22b
Crude proteína (%) 0.03 ± 0.003a 0.01 ± 0.003b
Fatty material (%) 0.05 ± 0.01a 0.04 ± 0.02a
Ash (%) 0.02 ± 0.01a 0.27 ± 0.02b
Purityb (%) 99.90 99.69
Colorimetric amylose (%) 10.79 ± 0.05a 3.66 ± 0.45b
DSC amylose 8.66 ± 0.00 ND
Phosphorous (%) 0.01 ± 0.00a 0.02 ± 0.00b
DSc (%) ND 0.002
DS: degree of substitution; ND: not detected by the method used; and DSC: differential scanning calorimetry.
Results are means of three determinations. Means with different letters in the same row differ significantly (p < 0.05). a
N × 6.25. b
Calculated from the equation: Purity (%) = 100 − (moisture content (%) + crude protein (%) + fatty materials (%) + ash (%)). c
Phosphate groups/anhydroglucose molecules.
The DS had shown 0.002% of phosphorous substitution on the starch by the method of modification, which is in compliance with the regulations of the FDA (maximum: 0.04%).35

Relative density, titratable acidity, and pH did not show significant statistical differences (p < 0.05) by the effect of the modification applied (Table 2). However, the color scale revealed differences, and a slight tendency to the white color value (low ΔE and high WI) in the modified starch was observed (Table 2). The tendency toward the white color of the modified starch may affect the transparency of the films. Table 2.
Physical and physicochemical properties of native and modified D. trifida starches
Parameters Native Modified
Relative density (g/mL) 1.51 ± 0.07a 1.57 ± 0.07a
pH 6.22 ± 0.0a 6.67 ± 0.03a
Titratable acidity (NaOH mEq/100 g) 0.0003 ± 0.000a 0.0002 ± 0.000a
Color scale
(L) 93.66 ± 0.00a 95.62 ± 0.03b
(a) 1.44 ± 0.00a 0.78 ± 0.00b
(b) 4.02 ± 0.02a 3.22 ± 0.01b
Total color difference (ΔE) 3.36 ± 0.00a 2.42 ± 0.02b
WI 92.36 ± 0.01a 94.51 ± 0.02b
WI: white index.
Results are means of three determinations. Means with different letters in the same row differ significantly (p < 0.05).

Values of aw of both types of films are low as expected (Table 3). Both starches have similar moisture contents, and there are no evidences or arguments indicating that the modification procedure should change aw values. Myllärinen et al.36 reported that amylose films at high relative humidity (RH%) absorb more water than amylopectin films. These authors also report that crystallization is known to decrease water sorption of the hydrophilic polymer and also that the lower water content in the amylopectin films may be explained by the amylopectin crystallization. Since amylose is mainly linear, whereas amylopectin is highly branched, the crystallinity of starch films is primarily associated with amylose, even if amylopectin accounts for the crystalline regions in the native starch granules. Consequently, starch films containing more amylose show higher crystallinity, which is contrary to the fact that native starch containing more amylose has a lower degree of crystallinity.36 Since, in this study, both the starches used (native and modified) have relatively low amylose contents (Table 1), a lower crystallinity should be expected accordingly. Also, García et al.,37 studying the micro-structural characterization of plasticized starch-based films, found that as the degree of crystallinity increased, the gas permeability of the film decreased. Table 3.
Physical and physicochemical properties of starch-based edible films using native and modified D. trifida starches
Parameters Starch-based edible films
From native starch From modified starch
pH 6.55 ± 0.02a 6.82 ± 0.02a
aw 0.42 ± 0.01a 0.43 ± 0.0a
Width (mm) 0.13 ± 0.01a 0.26 ± 0.01b
Penetration force (N) 1.10 ± 0.08a 3.00 ± 0.30b
Deformation (mm) 4.48 ± 0.17a 3.42 ± 0.40b
Color scale
(L) 19.39 ± 0.68 39.22 ± 0.61
(a) − 0.12 ± 0.04 − 0.47 ± 0.03
(b) − 7.60 ± 0.12 − 1.85 ± 0.13
Water permeability ( × 10−10g/msPa) 1.84 ± 0.90a 8.27 ± 1.62b
Water solubility (g ss/g total solids at 25°C) 0.30 ± 0.22a 0.54 ± 0.22b
Water retention (g gain water/g dry solids) 1.04 ± 0.47a 0.05 ± 0.02b
ss: soluble solids.
Results are means of three determinations. Means with different letters in the same row differ significantly (p < 0.05).

Significant differences (p < 0.05) in the width, color profile, deformation, and stress to puncture are found in the native starch based films, when comparing them with their modified counterparts (Table 3). The modified starch based films were wider and whiter than films from native starch, with lower tendencies to deformation. McHugh et al.,38 in a study of the effect of the thickness of films on water vapor permeability values, reported that as the thickness of the film was augmented, the water vapor permeability increased.

Several explanations have been provided for such thickness effect. Biofilms containing hydrophilic components, such as polysaccharides, have an extremely complex transport through them due to non-linear water sorption isotherms and water-content-dependent diffusivities.39 Thus, water vapor flux through hydrophilic films varies non-linearly with water vapor pressure gradient. It has been reported40 that this anomalous effect occurred because the swelling of hydrophilic matrix results in different structural changes in the films with different thicknesses. In this way, it is expected that hydrophilic films exhibit an increased permeability to water vapor, which is augmented by its thickness. The water solubility and water retention also were different between both films.

The water vapor permeability was higher in the modified starch, as compared to values of the native one. It could be explained by the augmented thickness of the films produced with modified starch.38 This behavior may be related to the structural network produced by the modifications on the starch. In addition, starch concentration and botanical source of the starch used may affect the water permeability properties of starch films.20,41

The water solubility values at 25°C of the films elaborated with native starch (0.30 ± 0.22) were significantly lower (p < 0.05) than those reported in the films elaborated with modified starch (0.54 ± 0.22). Some authors20 have reported values of water solubility for films obtained with non-conventional native starches; 32% (okenia), 23% (plantain), and 25% (mango). These authors had used conventional gelatinization with heat and cold gelatinization. Other authors40 report water solubility values ranging from 22.7% to 29.86% in films elaborated with oxidized potato starch, varying the glycerol concentration. López et al.,42 working with films produced with corn starch, reported that when using a large amount of glycerol, the water solubility increased. Sothornvit and Krochta43 suggest films with high water solubility for potential applications as edible wrappings for foods such as candies, because they can dissolve easily in the mouth.

The water retention is an important property to be measured on the films for food or pharmaceutical industries, because it defines the stability of the products where they are applied. In this study, there are differences between both the starches.

It is evident by the use of a magnifier that films were non-porous and transparent. However, the films produced using the modified starch was more opalescent than those produced with the native starch. As demonstrated through the procedure for film production (Figure 2), the degasification of the gel suspension was necessary to obtain a non-porous film. A relatively simple mixture of native or modified starch and plasticizer agents could integrate the conceive functions of foam production. The foam stability depends on numerous kinetic and non-equilibrium processes related to viscosity, surface tension, drainage, diffusion, capillarity, etc. The initial formation of foams or bubbles is facilitated by the reduction in surface tension, especially in the aqueous systems, and amphiphilic molecules can reduce this effect by forming (mono) layers at the interface, exposing less polar functional groups to the air while presenting a more water-compatible surface to the bulk liquid.44 Since this property was observed in the gelatinized starch–glycerol suspension before the degasification step, the speculation about its possible applications in the production of foam can be proposed.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: It is feasible to use non-conventional native and modified starches with appropriate physicochemical properties as bio-matrices for the elaboration of the edible films. Modifications brought about by cross-linking have an effect on the functional properties of the films, making them more white and more water permeable than their native counterpart. However, other specific uses can be proposed. More studies are required and the potential uses of waxy starches, native and modified, in foam should be investigated.

sec.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge the fund provided by the PROGRAMME DE COOPERATION POST-GRADUES (PCP) France-Venezuela, between the CIRAD at Montpellier, France and Instituto de Ciencia y Tecnología de Alimentos, Facultad de Ciencias Universidad Central de Venezuela in Caracas. Project “Aprovechamiento integral de raíces y tubérculos y musáceas comestibles cultivadas en Venezuela” No 2007002000.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors thank the local stakeholder in Venezuela for the identification and delivery of D. trifida tubers.
